The claim is supported by a report from: a policy analyst with the Georgia Budget & Policy Institute, who stated that Georgia has the ninth highest rate of adults, ages 18 to 64, without a high school diploma or GED.
The statistics cited in the claim were o: an initiative funded by reputable organizations such as the Ford Foundation and Annie Casey Foundation.
The claim is further supported by data f: s Office of Student Achievement, which reported that as of 2010, 16 percent of Georgia adults lacked a high school diploma or GED.
The claim is also backed up by the fact: Nathan Deal set a goal in 2011 to have an additional 250,000 Georgians with post-secondary school credentials by 2020, indicating recognition of the need to improve educational attainment in the state.
